posts.title: Boris Johnson’s Plan to Ditch the Withdrawal Agreement Shows His Mandate is Built on Lies
posts.short_desc: Boris Johnson won the 2019 election having secured, in his words, an ‘excellent’ withdrawal agreement for the UK. If he now undermines this agreement - potentially in favour of a no deal Brexit - his mandate will be built on lies, argues Aaron Bastani.

posts.title: Italy's Migrants Are Being Attacked From Left and Right. They Aren't Going to Take It Lying Down
posts.short_desc: As regional elections approach later this month, and with a second wave of coronavirus expected, the Italian far right and centre are engaged in a race to the bottom on immigration. Alice Figes looks at the latest chapter in Italy's long history of xenophobia.

posts.title: Labour's New Focus on 'Competence' Will Find Its Limits Once the Economic Downturn Hits
posts.short_desc: Against the initial wave of the pandemic, Keir Starmer has capitalised on popular frustration with the Tories' handling of the public health crisis. Yet as the national conversation pivots to the economic downturn, the Labour leader will struggle without economic propositions of his own, writes Oliver Eagleton.

posts.title: An Everyday Anarchist: David Graeber, 1961-2020
posts.short_desc: David Graeber - anthropologist, author, anarchist and friend to many - died this week in Venice aged 59. A lifelong fighter for social justice, his ultimate achievement will be in the “everyday communist society” we create, writes Paul Mason.

posts.title: The Cosmic Right Is on the Rise in the UK. The Left Must Fight It With Reason
posts.short_desc: QAnon and the 'cosmic right' are gaining traction in the UK by re-enchanting a mundane world and offering easy solutions to complex problems. Political economist Keir Milburn argues that the left should use the best weapon in its armoury to fight this worrying trend: reason.

posts.title: The Opposite of a Cynic: David Graeber, 1961-2020
posts.short_desc: Novara Media would likely not exist without anthropologist and activist David Graeber, who died on Wednesday. He helped give us the confidence to start out, and the conviction that left media – and especially left media that is able to think for itself – actually matters, writes James Butler.

posts.title: Labour Is Hemorrhaging Leftwing Activists. Will It Survive?
posts.short_desc: Thousands of Labour activists who were galvanised by the prospect of a Corbyn government have lost hope in Starmer's Labour - and are leaving the party in droves. Harriet Williamson speaks to some of them.

posts.title: I Witnessed Labour Staff Working to Undermine Jeremy Corbyn's Leadership
posts.short_desc: As John McDonnell's economic advisor, James Meadway saw Labour staff work to undermine the leadership through a steady drip-drip-drip of small, deliberate failures, which, he writes, added up to major dysfunction, almost certainly costing the party the 2017 election.

posts.title: 'Land justice is racial justice': People of Colour Are Reclaiming Their Right to Nature
posts.short_desc: While the UK land justice movement has gained momentum in recent years, the significance of land in the struggle for racial justice remains largely undiscussed. Yali Banton-Heath speaks with Josina Calliste, co-founder of Land in Our Names, a collective helping people of colour to the land, about the necessity of centring land access and food sovereignty within the wider struggle for racial justice.

posts.title: Beyond Bernie: How the Democratic National Convention Sidelined Progressives
posts.short_desc: In the wake of the Democratic National Convention, which saw the party become the mouthpiece of bipartisan corporate elites, progressives at the Democratic base are growing more disillusioned than ever. Freddie Stuart takes a closer look in the fifth instalment of Beyond Bernie, a series tracking the US elections.
